Manuscript description based on Margoliouth, G.: Catalogue of the Hebrew and Samaritan Manuscripts in the British Museum, London 1965.

msContents.summary: Sefer ha-terumah by Barukh ben Isaac of Worms.

collation.p: 36 quires: i8-3 (folios 1-5), ii-xiii8-101), xiv10-1 (folios 102-110), xv-xxxiv8 (folios 111-270), xxxv8-1 (folios 271-277), xxxvi three (folios 278-280).

scriptDesc.scriptNote: Ashkenazi semi-cursive script of the 13th centur, unpunctuated. The name Elazar is marked on folio 221r, Shim῾on is marked on folio 249r.

binding.p: Post-1600. Red leather, tooled in gold. Spine title: 'Barukh b. Isaac. Sefer Hatterumah. Hebrew. Brit. Mus. Harley Or. 5648.'

history.provenance: Acquisition: The Harley Collection, formed by Robert Harley (b. 1661, d. 1724), 1st earl of Oxford and Mortimer, politician, and Edward Harley (b. 1689, d. 1741), 2nd earl of Oxford and Mortimer, book collector and patron of the arts[, inscribed as usual by their librarian, Humfrey Wanley, ‘18 die January, A.D. 1723/4’ (folio 278r). Edward Harley bequeathed the library to his widow, Henrietta Cavendish, née Holles (b. 1694, d. 1755) during her lifetime and thereafter to their daughter, Margaret Cavendish Bentinck (b. 1715, d. 1785), duchess of Portland; the manuscripts were sold by the Countess and the Duchess in 1753 to the nation for £10,000 (a fraction of their contemporary value) under the Act of Parliament that also established the British Museum; the Harley manuscripts form one of the foundation collections of the British Library.
